The page's name is 'question mark?'.

fields.description:
h5. Steps to reproduce
# Create a table in rich text editor
# Input a horizontal rule in one of the table cell with a text following up after the horizontal rule
# Do a round trip to Wiki Markup and back to Rich Text Editor. Similarly, you can also save the page and the same result will be displayed

h5. Screenshots
[^RichTextFirst.png]
[^WikiRoundTrip.png]
[^RichTextAfterRoundTrip.png]
[^WikiMarkupAfterRoundTrip2.png]
fields.summary: Horizontal rule within a table cell changes to dashes after roundtrips
Dependency checking for Office connector and WebDAV plugin

fields.description:
At the moment all our styling is kept in master.css, we should move this out into its own file for ease of use.

It also needs to be added to the super batch.
fields.summary: Separate admin styles into its own file

fields.description:
Set the site theme to Fixed Width.

The Dashboard now has the fixed borders,but some macros can overlap this border.

In particular: TaskDock and Favourite Pages - see screenshots

fields.description:
We recently migrated our user management from JIRA to Crowd, our Confluence instance used to link to JIRA for authentication, and now links to Crowd.

We now found that, when editing the restrictions on individual pages, the autocomplete feature in that dialog acts strange:
* Users that have been deleted since the migration suddenly turn up in the drop-down box. Those users may however still be present in the internal user database of Confluence/JIRA, but that database shouldn't be used anymore since the move to Crowd. It's definitely not being used for authentication, so why does the autocomplete box still use it? When i select one of those users, It tells me the user can't be found, so it's purely an autocomplete issue.
* Our usernames have spaces in them, ie. 'joris vandermeersch' is my username. When I type 'jo' in the box, my username comes up as autocomplete suggestion, but when i select it, I get an error "Unknown user or group: joris+vandermeersch". When I type my name out fully in the box, then press enter, ignoring the autocomplete suggestions, my username is found correctly and added to the restrictions.

Are we doing something wrong in our configuration, or are these indeed bugs in the autocomplete system?
fields.summary: autocomplete box in page restrictions finds deleted users, wrong usernames

User can still apply page-level restrictions to their Personal Space if additional access is to be granted/restricted.

fields.description:
The following page provides instructions on how to add a localisation property file to your {{atlassian-plugin.xml}} file:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Adding+Plugin+and+Module+Resources

Essentially, the instructions indicate that you need to add a resource similar in the following in your {{atlassian-plugin.xml}} file:

{noformat}
<!-- For the localisation property file below, it must be named exampleplugin.properties -->
<!-- located under the resources folder -->
<resource type="i18n" name="i18n" location="resources/exampleplugin" />
{noformat}

However, when I recently developed a Confluence macro plugin using the Atlassian Plugin SDK, I had to append '_en' to the core filename (i.e. not the extension part), so that my plugin would use my localisation property file (i.e. the localised text would appear in the Macro Browser).

In my case, I had to change 'i18n.properties' to 'i18n_en.properties'.

I'm not sure if this has anything to do with my having developed my plugin using the Atlassian Plugin SDK.
fields.summary: When developing Confluence plugins (with the Atlassian Plugin SDK), the generic localisation property file is not (always) being used.

fields.description:
A customer reported that his user was not able to edit a Confluence page that has grown to 320K of markup and 63,000 lines.

If he is editing directly via http://localhost:8080 it works fine, but failed if he is using IE or Firefox via Apache. Interestingly, editing via Apache works when his user uses Chrome.

By failed, he meant the save attempt will result in a time out. No error in atlassian-confluence.log nor catalina.out

The point is, it might be a good idea to limit page length for the following reasons:
# They cannot be edited on major web browsers.
# Pages with that length are difficult to follow.
# It helps Confluence administrators to administer Confluence better.

It would be a good idea to have have this functionality available in the administration console.
fields.summary: Limit Confluence page length
Add the ability to serve static resources like images from hosts other than the one in the base URL

fields.description:
I installed a Confluence plugin containing a gadget module. The gadget module referred to a gadget spec residing on the same Confluence instance. (I stored my gadget spec (XML file) as an attachment to a Confluence page. That seemed handy.)

The Confluence startup procedure found the gadget plugin and went looking for the gadget spec. It waited and waited and waited... Confluence would not start up.

Question: Does the startup procedure really need to check for the gadget spec?

Suggestion: If yes, then Confluence should not wait indefinitely if it cannot find the spec. Instead, it should time out.

See attached thread dump.
fields.summary: Confluence startup should time out after a reasonable period if it can't find a gadget spec referenced by a plugin

fields.description:
[copied from forum post: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=40186]

I've been using some macros on Confluence 3.0 that internally render the XHTML code before performing additional operations, e.g. they have the form:

{code}
#set( $globalHelper = $action.getGlobalHelper() )
#set( $renderer = $globalHelper.getWikiStyleRenderer() )
#set( $context = $content.toPageContext() )
#set( $renderedContent = $renderer.convertWikiToXHtml($context, $output).trim() )
{code}

However, the 'getGlobalHelper' method on the ConfluenceActionSupport object (i.e. here on the $action instance variable) has been removed in Confluence 3.1, disabling all macros using this method.
I have searched in vain for an alternative way of instantiating a WikiStyleRenderer object from within a user macro (i.e. via the Confluence Admin -> User Macros interface).

The only similar method is the 'renderConfluenceMacro' method (accessed by getting the ThemeHelper object via $action.getHelper(), but this doesn't do what I need (I need to be able to submit wiki markup with the page context included, as in the code above).

I'm assuming I only have access within a macro to the objects listed on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Confluence+Objects+Accessible+From+Velocity

It was suggested I file a bug for this, although I am open to any alternatives that ideally don't require me to create a plug-in for this functionality.
fields.summary: WikiStyleRenderer object inaccessible from user macros since ConfluenceActionSupport.getGlobalHelper() method removed in v. 3.1

Fixes for this issue will include a combination of...
* getting the appropriate user-specified colour to apply
* changing the CSS so it simply inherits the right colour
* changing the override so it sets a reasonable neutral colour (usually black, white or grey)

fields.description:
The quick search breaks at the first non-ascii character.

Steps to reproduce:
- create a page named "Thöggele"
- wait until it is indexed
- try finding the page via quick search by entering "T" and "h" (everything is ok)
- press "ö" (you will see that nothing changes on the UI, especially the ö in Thöggele is not bold), and the search is not narrowed

Fix:
- in the file (3.1, similar in 3.0) 
  confluence-3.1-std/confluence/WEB-INF/classes/com/atlassian/confluence/setup/atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip, and inside there
  auiplugin-2.0.2.1.jar
- patch the file 
   js/atlassian/atlassian.js
  the function "escape" like this:
{code}
  339,341c339
<                 return escape(string).replace(/%u\w{4}/gi, function (w) {
<                     return unescape(w);
<                 });
---
>                 return encodeURIComponent(string);
{code}
- re-package the jar and zip and place it in the original file location, and restart confluence, and try again. It works now :-)

Installed confluence from a zip file. Had run the installer previously but realised it was an evaluation version, so I uninstalled the evaluation version and set up the zip according to instructions supplied.

I am currently having trouble installing the service using {{service.bat install "Confluence31"}}:

{code}
D:\Confluence\confluence-3.1-std\bin>Service2 install Confluence31
Installing the service 'Confluence31' ...
Using CATALINA_HOME:    "D:\Confluence\confluence-3.1-std"
Using CATALINA_BASE:    "D:\Confluence\confluence-3.1-std"
Using JAVA_HOME:        "D:\Java\jdk1.6.0_17"

Failed installing 'Confluence31' service
{code}

I also created my own batch file to install service:

{code}
@echo off

set PR_DESCRIPTION=Apache Tomcat Server - Confluence
set PR_INSTALL=D:\Confluence\confluence-3.1-std\bin\tomcat6.exe
set PR_LOGPATH=D:\Confluence\confluence-3.1-std\logs
set PR_LOGLEVEL=debug
set PR_LOGPREFIX=joel.log

--StopClass=org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap --StopParams=stop

echo errorlevel=%errorlevel%

returns {{errorlevel=7}}

For both actions above, the same message appears in the log (debug is returned from the latter)

{code}
[2010-01-08 10:45:40] [1334 prunsrv.c] [debug] Procrun log initialized
[2010-01-08 10:45:40] [info] Procrun (2.0.3.0) started
[2010-01-08 10:45:40] [532  prunsrv.c] [debug] Installing service...
[2010-01-08 10:45:41] [info] Service Confluence31 name Apache Tomcat Confluence31

If anyone can confirm that confluence can be installed on Windows 2003 standard will all service packs installed, that would be a help.

Basically, sending all values not equal to "Import" to the Advanced Doc Import page. If this is true, this problem is occurring for all language packs other than English as well.

fields.description:
When an RSS Feed is requested, Confluence renders all pages into the resulting XML.

This can be *computationally intensive* for certain macros, especially the *SQL Macro*.

If people are subscribed to wide-ranging feeds such as 'New Pages' or 'Changed Pages', this can cause many such pages to render. Many of these rendering passes are for *no benefit to humans, since RSS Readers refresh feeds on a regular basis, especially Google Reader which refreshes every 30 minutes even if nobody is currently using Google Reader!*

Further, the feeds cannot be cached because they are dependent upon each individual user's security privileges.

*The result:* Goole Reader refreshes the feed 48 times a day, causing computationally intesive pages to render for no human benefit, and it does this for every separate user who has subscribed. Other RSS Readers update less frequently, but still annoyingly.

*Recommendation:* Do not render the SQL macro in RSS Feeds. There may also be other macros that are best avoided. (Perhaps a flag in the plugin that indicates whether to render in RSS Feeds?)

It is especially the case on Atlassian's own Extranet that this causes high load.
fields.summary: RSS Feeds: Do not render computationally intensive macros in RSS Feeds due to frequent rendering to RSS Readers
